act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Sam Black went and checked in with the workers who make those products and found lots of people in the middle and, interestingly, even among the people whose jobs were not saved, lots were still feeling hopeful about Donald Trump. Here's Sam.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: The workers I met who voted for Trump, whether their jobs were saved or not, most of them were pretty lukewarm about the new president. Not hardcore "make America great again" types. One white man in his 50s told me that Trump's comments about women made him ashamed to be a man, but he voted for him anyway. A black guy in his 30s said he'd walked into the voting booth planning to go for Clinton, put his pen to her name, but then thought he couldn't trust her and changed to Trump.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Then there was Georgina. She says she was initially for Bernie Sanders all the way, but in November she went for Trump.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Were you excited when he was elected?

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: Kinda.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Georgina's been working at the same factory for 25 years. She makes just over $16 an hour plus benefits, enough to live a decent life in the small town of Huntington, where her company, UTEC, is the largest employer. She's 48, raised three kids, and has 10 grandkids.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Her employer, UTEC, is the sister company to Carrier. It makes the circuit boards that go into Carrier air conditioners and furnaces. She really likes her job.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: As far as factories go, that is the easiest work that you will ever find. Ever. I mean, it's air conditioned and it's got good heat. It's clean. You can wear white to work and not worry about it.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Carrier became part of the presidential campaign about a year ago when the company announced it was closing its Indianapolis plant. That same morning, UTEC, where Georgina works, called all the workers into the cafeteria. Same deal. 700 people would lose their jobs.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: It was devastating. People were crying. Everybody was just stunned and very, very quiet. And once he said that, honestly, I don't know what was said after that. I have no idea because so many things were racing through my head.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: 10 months later, after Donald Trump won the election-- you may have seen this-- he went to the Carrier plant in Indianapolis to announce he'd made a deal.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: donald trump
utterance: I want to thank Greg Hayes of United Technologies because when I called him, he was right there.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: I waited to see how many jobs were saved, whose jobs were saved. I got excited, and I was sitting on pins and needles.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: donald trump
utterance: --is it's so great. So many people in that big, beautiful plant behind us, they're so happy. They're going to have a great Christmas.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Here was Trump's bargain. In exchange for a $7 million tax break, Carrier would keep about 800 jobs in Indianapolis. More than 1,300 jobs would still go to Mexico, including Georgina's.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: And when I realized, yeah, then I got a little upset and then disappointment.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: donald trump
utterance: These companies aren't going to be leaving anymore. They're not going to be taking people's hearts out.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: Then watching all of them celebrate--

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: donald trump
utterance: Thank you. Thank you very much.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: That was a little depressing. It was hard to watch. Yeah, I was sad.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Georgina says that what bothered her was that Trump acted like he accomplished more than he did. And it felt like it was all about him, a publicity stunt, a victory lap at her expense. He could have at least mentioned the workers he didn't help.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: Acknowledge us-- not just us, but the ones at Indy that you didn't save, and these other factories that are all shutting down, not just us. Acknowledge them.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: That would have meant something to you.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: It would have. I don't think that I would have thought that it was just for good press then. I would think, he's really going to try. He's going to do the best he can for everybody.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Georgina told me she thinks Trump's deal mostly benefited the company, which pocketed millions and still laid off 1,300 people. Another worker put it this way. Imagine getting fired by a company with billion-dollar profits and then finding out that your tax dollars are picking up their tab. It's like you're subsidizing your own layoff.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: But despite all this, Georgina still holds out hope for the new president. In his campaign, Donald Trump talked about putting 35% tariffs on companies that send jobs offshore. Georgina hopes that was more than just a campaign promise. And in fact, after she and I talked, Trump brought it up at his first press conference.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: donald trump
utterance: The word is now out that when you want to move your plant to Mexico or some other place and you want to fire all of your workers from Michigan and Ohio and all these places that I won for good reason, it's not going to happen that way anymore. You're going to pay a very large border tax. A major border tax on these companies that are leaving and getting away with murder.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: georgina
utterance: I think that Trump really does want to help keep the jobs in the US. And I don't know yet. He might be the best president we've ever had. I have no idea.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: Georgina doesn't remember any other presidential candidate even bothering to talk about workers like her, except Bernie Sanders.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: On inauguration day, Georgina was at work. She could be laid off as early as April. Her plan? Go to night school, get trained for administrative work in a hospital, making less than she does now.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: How do you expect you'll feel watching him being inaugurated as president?

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: donald trump
utterance: Hopeful, because I want him to prove me wrong, that he is going to try and save these other people's jobs. Not ours. I know that's not going to happen, but there's other places that are talking about leaving and maybe he can save those.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: sam black
utterance: But the truth is, Georgina says she rarely thinks about the man she helped elect. Maybe once a week when someone at work jokes about his latest tweet.

act_title: Act Four: You Are Still Fired
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Sam Black. He's a documentary filmmaker in New York.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Act Five, Debate is Not Allowed During a Vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So for the Democrats, what is life about to look like without control of the White House, House, or Senate? Well, one little preview happened earlier this month at around 1:00 in the morning on the Senate floor. It was the vote that would start the process of dismantling Obamacare. Democrats knew they would lose, but for the next few years things are going to happen that they do not like and are powerless to stop. All they could do that night was try to make a statement while voting no, though the other side controls even how much of a statement they get to make. Here's an excerpt of how the vote went down.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Mrs. Gillibrand.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: kirsten gillibrand
utterance: I vote no on behalf of all the women who need health--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Senator is not exempt. Debate is not allowed during the vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Mrs. Gillibrand, no. Mr. Schatz.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: brian schatz
utterance: I vote no on behalf of people who need mental health care.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Debate is not allowed during the vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Mr. Schatz, no.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Gentleman from Illinois.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: dick durbin
utterance: On behalf of the Downstate hospitals of Illinois, I vote--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Debate is not in order during a vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Mr. Durbin, no. Ms. Klobuchar.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: amy klobuchar
utterance: Because there is no plan in the alternative--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Debate is not allowed--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: amy klobuchar
utterance: --I vote no.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: --will be in order.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Ms. Klobuchar, no.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: [INAUDIBLE] order. Debate is not in order during a vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Debate is not an order during a vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Debate is not in order during a vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Mr. Kaine.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: tim kaine
utterance: When I was sick, you visited me--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Debate is not allowed during a vote. The Senate will be in order.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Mr. Kaine, no. Ms. Heitkamp.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: heidi heitkamp
utterance: On behalf of the thousands of--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Senator will suspend.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: heidi heitkamp
utterance: --people who receive health care in my state and rural hospital--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Debate is not allowed.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: heidi heitkamp
utterance: --who know not how they're going to get her health care--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Senator will suspend.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: heidi heitkamp
utterance: --if this passes without--

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Clerk will begin a roll vote.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: heidi heitkamp
utterance: --without a replacement, I vote no.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Senator will suspend.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: clerk
utterance: Ms. Heitkamp, no.

act_title: Act Five: Debate Is Not Allowed During a Vote
speaker: presiding officer
utterance: Is there any senator in the debate-- in the chamber that wishes to change their vote or vote? On this vote, the yeas are 51. The nays are 48. The concurrent resolution is agreed to.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Act Six, Office Climate and Climate Office.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: ira glass
utterance: So any new president gets to appoint over 4,000 people to various positions, but most of the people in those big buildings in Washington DC are not those 4,000 people. They are civil servants. Most of them stay in their jobs from one administration to the next, whoever's in power. Not all of them. Our producer David Kestenbaum spoke with a couple of civil servants in DC who were deciding whether to stick around.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Laura works at the Department of Energy, one of the agencies that seems like it might change dramatically under the new president. She asked us not to use her real name and to have an actor do her voice, even though she knows that's probably overkill.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: She says as a civil servant you're supposed to keep your politics and your job separate. Your job is to enact the policies of whoever's in power, Democrat or Republican. But the first day back after the election it was hard to keep her politics to herself.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: I've never cried at work before. When you cry, you can't hide the fact afterwards-- at least for me, my face gets really red. So I had a meeting or whatever. I just had to be like, sorry, I just had a moment. And then everybody else was like, yeah, we did, too. It's not just you.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: I don't want to get into too much detail, but your job is climate change-related?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Yes.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: How many people at DoE do you think are unconvinced that humans are causing global warming?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: I don't know anyone at DoE who thinks that.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Do you think it's literally zero?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Probably zero or close to zero.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: It looked like that number would rise by at least one. Rick Perry, Trump's pick to run the DoE, had written in his own book that he thought the science showing humans were contributing to climate change was a, quote, "contrived phony mess."

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: As you may have heard, Trump's team sent a list of questions to the DoE asking, among other things, the names of people who had attended UN climate change meetings. Democrats saw it as a kind of witch hunt.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Rick Perry now says his views on climate change have changed and that he didn't approve of the questionnaire. But after the election, Laura spent a lot of time wondering, should I stay in this job? What would it be like? What if the new bosses ask me to do something I just think is wrong?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Like what if there were some report or something and someone asked you to take out all the references to climate change?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Well, we already did that.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: You already did that?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Yeah, we have.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Laura says she and a bunch of other people have been going through all their internal documents that describe ongoing projects and just scrubbing them, deleting the parts where it says, "and here's how this will help us combat climate change." Laura didn't want to talk specifics, but you could imagine a satellite for monitoring climate change and saying, think of it as a weather satellite instead. This renewable energy program? Now it's a jobs program.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Most federal projects have a bunch of reasons for their existence. Why draw attention to something by putting the words "climate change" in the description?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Did it feel sad to take it out?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: No.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Because you thought, this is a way we can get by?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Yeah, exactly. That was my thought. As long as it's getting done, it doesn't matter what we call it.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Laura's entire time at the DoE has been under Obama. She's never been through a change of power before. That first day after the election, there was this big all-staff meeting at the DoE. That made her feel a little better-- not because it was emotional, but because it wasn't. It was professional, just like, here's what happens next.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: I think what made it OK was it was very matter-of-fact. Like, the transition team is going to come in in the next few days. They didn't. They came in like several weeks later.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: When the transition team did arrive at DoE, Laura went on what felt like a kid detective mission to try to see the invaders. She knew they were on the fifth floor, so she went up there with a friend. They tried to play it cool, had to do a couple laps because they missed the room the first time. But there it was.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: It literally said on the door, "transition team." And I elbowed my friend, and she was like, I saw it. It wasn't like something was hidden or something, but I felt very like, oh, wow. There it is.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Somehow seeing the office make you feel more reassured?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Yeah, because the name was on the door. It's one of these things. It's like, well, they're not trying to hide anything. They're just there doing their job.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: I talked to this other government worker who we'll call Karen. Karen's a relatively senior person. She served under a Democrat and a Republican. Karen says a bunch of younger coworkers have been coming into her office, closing the door, and saying, do you have a minute to talk? It's like she's become a therapist. Some of the people are trying to figure out what to do-- stay or leave. If you stay, at least you can try to steer things. Or you can fight.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: And by fight, I mean that in the most bureaucratic way possible. Government moves very slowly, which is a pain when you're trying to get things done. But if you're trying to stop something from happening, it can be used to your advantage.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: karen
utterance: Withholding information is one way you slow things down. The bureaucracy is large. There's a lot of paperwork, a lot of steps, and people that have been in government for a long time understand all those steps really well. So some of those tactics may be used to make things go a lot slower.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: One government worker told me he knew some people who were really good at this. It's like the dark arts of civil service. You can refer things to the general counsel for legal review. That takes time. You can also try to hide things.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: One relatively senior official who recently left government has been advising those who stayed behind to just lay low, keep any controversial stuff under the radar. Karen knows that trick.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: karen
utterance: It's not like you can come into the government and, with the click of a button, find everything you need to know on any topic we've worked on for the last 15 years.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: So literally, there might be like programs or documents or things that are just so well hidden that they'd never find out about them?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: karen
utterance: You could say that.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Are people talking about doing that kind of stuff?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: karen
utterance: I think people don't know yet how they will react because they are waiting to see if what they are predicting may happen does come to pass.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: But if it does?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: karen
utterance: There are definitely some career civil servants that will not ever give in, and I think there are definitely some career civil servants that will toe the line. But I think the people that know how the system works have used these tactics within many administrations.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Sounds kind of wrong. It doesn't seem like the right thing to do.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: karen
utterance: I think when you've worked on something for a long time and you've devoted your entire career to it and you believe it is the right thing to do, people will do their jobs. But when they think that what they are doing is harmful to citizens or the country in the long run, I think they will stand up for what they believe in the bureaucratic ways that they can.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Karen is not going to be doing any of that. I imagine that's true of most people. They'll either do their jobs like good civil servants or they'll just leave. Karen is leaving. It didn't take her long to decide. She knew almost immediately, on election night.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: karen
utterance: I remember saying to a close friend, wow, I'll be departing from my job in January. And I'm a career public servant. [SOBS] I'm sorry.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Laura, at the Department of Energy, took longer to make up her mind. Senior people there-- Democrats-- were urging people to stay under Trump. Don't leave, they said. We need good people here. If you leave, you don't know who will replace you. And you don't know how bad it'll be. Maybe it'll be OK.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: It was that questionnaire that sealed things for her, the one that made the news and asked for the names of people who had attended UN climate change talks. Laura wasn't in the office when the news broke. She heard about it by email from a friend in another part of government.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Well, she was like, this doesn't look good, basically. And I was like, on the contrary, this is kind of funny.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: It seemed like such an amateur move. The DoE, by the way, refused to provide any names.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: That just seemed like a scare tactic to me, and I didn't want to reward that sort of brazen attempt to get people to leave the agency. I'm not leaving.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Are you thinking like, I can last four years?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: I think I can last four years.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Could you last eight?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: I probably wouldn't stay for eight, no.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: What are you doing for the inauguration?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Probably hanging out with my friends in a bar.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Watching it or avoiding it?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Not watching it. I've already seen enough of him to last a lifetime.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: Well, she's going to be seeing more of him, as she knows.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: We have these pictures hanging up in every office of the president, the vice president, the secretary of energy, and they're all going to change.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: You're going to have a picture of Donald Trump in your office?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: Yes. And Mike Pence and Rick Perry and whoever the undersecretary is.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: How do you feel about that?

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: laura
utterance: I don't know. At least-- I mean, like-- that's like-- [SIGHS] it's just a reminder of the world we live in every day. I think you can bury your head a little bit and try to keep doing what you're doing, but there are people you answer to and that picture makes you remember who they are.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: david kestenbaum
utterance: We looked into it. The portraits of Obama and his officials were scheduled to be removed on Friday at noon, the exact time Donald Trump took the oath of office. We were told the pictures would be disposed of respectfully. In my mind, there's a big dumpster somewhere with all of the photos in it, like an actual dustbin of history. The frames do get saved and reused for the new portraits. They're going to be going up in the next few weeks.

act_title: Act Six: A Change In The Office Climate
speaker: ira glass
utterance: David Kestenbaum is one of the producers of our program. The actor who performed Laura's quotes is Jen Davis.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Our program was produced today by David Kestenbaum. Our production staff includes Susan Burton, Zoe Chace, Dana Chivvas, Sean Cole, Neil Drumming, Karen Duffin, Emmanuel Dzotsi, Stephanie Foo, Chana Joffe-Walt, Miki Meek, Jonathan Menjivar, Robyn Semien, Matt Tierney, Nancy Updike, and Diane Wu. Research help today from Christopher Swetala and Michelle Harris. Music help today from Damian Graef.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: Our website, thisamericanlife.org. This American Life is delivered to public radio stations by PRX, the Public Radio Exchange. Thanks as always to our show's co-founder Mr. Torey Malatia. He does not understand why the president's motorcade has to cause so much traffic whenever he's driving around New York heading to Trump Tower.

act_title: Credits
speaker: kenia
utterance: Like, he has legs.

act_title: Credits
speaker: ira glass
utterance: I'm Ira Glass. Back next week with more stories of This American Life.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: From WBEZ Chicago, it's This American Life. I'm Ira Glass.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: OK. Let's agree on facts.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: We all had hope of going to USA.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Nairobi, Kenya. Saturday, the day after President Trump signed his executive order temporarily stopping all refugees from entering the United States. This is a transit center for refugees, run by the International Organization for Migration, the IOM, which helps them relocate.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: In a tent, about 40 Somalis sit on plastic chairs-- mostly men. They're banned from the United States for two reasons, if you want to get technical about it. Because they're refugees, and because they're from one of the seven countries where we're banning all travelers-- from Somalia.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: A middle aged Kenyan, George Okech, stands in front of them with the unenviable job of explaining the news. Many of these men were supposed to fly in the next two or three days.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: And as it is now, you know that there is a new president in the office of USA.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: So for this reason, are you are aware that some changes will come in?

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: For your information, it's not only in Kenya, but many other places, too.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: This is beyond our control. We don't have a final say here. Are you aware of that?

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Yeah. I mean, people are really sad, just some of them with their heads in their hands.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Kevin Sieff is the Africa bureau chief for The Washington Post. He was there recording what happened for us.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Some of them had been refugees for 25, 26 years. I would say probably the majority of them had been refugees for more than two decades.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Oh, my God.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Yeah. And so I mean, these are people, in many cases, who submitted their applications to go to the US 10, 12 years ago. And that's how long it took them to get to this step in the process, this last step.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: This last step, though, is now blocked.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: What the president has said is final. We can't question him.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: It is final for me.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: Final for IOM.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: Final for you.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: Neither you or us should start fighting about it.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: So the process now will be people will have to go back to the camp.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: The camp is the refugee camp seven hours away, where they lived.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: So we have just to move you back there.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: As we all wait.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: How would you take that?

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: The problem with moving back is, OK, everything. But the practical part of it is daunting. They sold their homes and possessions, gave up their jobs. And they were no longer on the books as camp residents. People running the camp weren't sure what to do with that. George asked the group, what are some of the problems?

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: What are some of the problems that you are facing if you go back may I ask you? One by one, not everybody. One by one.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: Yes, Mr. Ahmed?

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: He is in 26 years.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: Yes.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: At the camp?

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: At the camp level, yes.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: He's saying he's been at the camp for 26 years.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: And when he was called by IOM to go for flights, he took, for shopping, clothes credits from one of the shopkeepers. And that shopkeeper is expecting him to pay back that credit.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Kevin, just explain what's being said here.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: So before these guys left their refugee camps, they bought a lot of clothes to bring with them for the journey. The clothes are cheaper there and they kind of wanted to arrive already having American clothes, already having winter jackets. I think there was this idea that they could come out of whatever American airport they'd arrived at and already be prepared. There was a lot of pride, I think, attached to that.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: But, Kevin explained to me, because they didn't have any money, they bought all the clothes on credit with the idea that they were going to earn the money in America and then send it back.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: And so that was one of their biggest concerns was how are they going to pay back this huge sum of money. They'd never considered it. And so even if they only spent, I don't know-- I think most of them spent around $100 on clothes. That's an unimaginable amount of money to make for almost all of these people.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Because working a job in the camp, how much would you make a day?

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Some of the highest paid people in the camp are teachers, and they make $80 a month. So to pay back $100-- they're really worried about having these confrontations with the people who they basically borrowed large sums of money from.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: So George tells the refugees.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: Your creditors--

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: You'll have to talk to them.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: Because you are not yet in America.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: And it wasn't to your liking.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: And if you promise that you are going to work hard to pay back.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: That is something explainable to somebody.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: It is not easy.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: But it is something that we have to swallow, though bitter.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: George calls in another guy, a skinny guy in his 20s with a goatee. He used to be a headmaster of a school in the camp. He says that, while he was waiting for his papers to come to the United States, he turned down scholarships in Canada and Germany. The one in Canada included a path to citizenship. And he did that because he wanted to go to America. After the four-month temporary ban, he asks, are we going to be allowed into the United States? George replies.

ep-609.speaker: george okech
ep-609.utterance: Remember I said that this is a bitter pill and there is nothing we can do about it. We don't want to give you any false promise. We don't know what will be said and put into effect by the end of 120 days. The boss has said wait. And once he has said wait, nobody will change it till he decides otherwise.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: The boss? He means President Trump.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Yeah, that's right.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: This is like the worst town hall meeting ever. It's like each person stands up and says something awful about the situation, and then the guy in the front of the room says, yes, this is a bitter pill.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: And there's also just no clarity for them. One of the things that struck me while I was at the transit center is that every time someone prepared to speak to the refugees, there was this false hope. Like, they all gathered around in these plastic chairs and waited for good news. And it happened a lot. They were gathered around in a group and basically told that nothing had changed. But each time before that person, like George, started speaking, there was this expectation. And you could feel it that maybe they're going to say now that the suspension's been lifted.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Fact is, at the end of 120 day ban on entering the United States, for many, if not most, of these refugees, clearances and their applications will expire. So they're going have to clear those again, which could take years.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Our country does lots of things around the world that have unintended consequences, but this is the intended consequence of the travel ban. These refugees were stopped until the administration could toughen up the vetting process to enter the United States. In the first week of the Trump administration, there was a lot of talk about dealing with illegal immigrants to the US, about building a wall, about how we were going to pay for that.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: But immigrants who followed the rules, who filled out the forms, who went through the process-- they were fine. Not this week. With the signing of this executive order, the president made the transition from cracking down on illegal immigrants to cracking down on legal ones. All the people at this camp were legal immigrants. They'd gone through a rigorous vetting process that had taken years, had been approved for resettlement, and now they're barred from the country.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Today on our radio show, we're going to document some of the things that happened when the executive order went into effect, and we're going to talk about the way it was implemented. As I'm guessing you've already heard, customs agents didn't have clear instructions. Government agencies said they weren't properly consulted. There was no advance warning to agencies or to travelers, so people got on planes and then had to be turned back from airports. It was like seeing a major policy change thrown into the world like a fastball with no warning. And it's hard not to feel like, what just happened? Like, what was that all about? We talk about that, too.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: About half the country approves of the ban according to a Reuters poll. But if you took a poll at this transit center, I'm pretty confident the numbers would not be that high. Kevin talked to one guy, Ahmed, who's 24. Born in the refugee camp. And until he went to the transit center, he said he'd never been outside the camp.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: And that's really common at that camp in Dadaab. Dadaab is the biggest refugee camp in the world. There are 270,000 people there.

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: It's very sad. Can I ask you a question?

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Yeah.

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: Are you from America?

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Yeah, I'm from America. It's called Fort Lauderdale.

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: So how do you feel, only surrounds that city?

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: He's asking you, how would you feel if you never left Fort Lauderdale?

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: How would you feel? You personally?

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Yeah, I think it would be hard. And also, Fort Lauderdale is much bigger than your camp.

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: Exactly. Yeah. That's how is it.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: So let me ask you. When you're sitting in Ifo camp and you're trying to imagine America-- far away; it looks different-- how do you imagine it in your head?

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: In fact, when I had started this process, I used to just dream at night that I, in America, I'm just driving a bus. You see, just walking--

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: You're driving a bus in the dream?

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Wait, wait. He's saying that in his dream of living in America, he's a bus driver?

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Yeah. That's the thing that he really latched onto.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Why do you think in the dream you were driving a bus? I'm just wondering.

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: I like driving.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: Have you ever driven a car?

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: No.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: You've never driven a car?

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: I never drive a car here. [INAUDIBLE] America around there.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: It case this isn't clear, these are literal dreams, like while he was asleep. He would be in America, driving a bus, and then Ahmed said he would wake up and, you know, he'd be back at the camp.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: So after working their way through the application process-- some of them taking a decade doing it-- Ahmed and the other Somalis find out at the 11th hour, no, they are not going to America. And in fact, they're going to be returning to the refugee camp where they'd given up their jobs and their homes. And in fact, they were now in debt for their new American winter coats and pants.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: I mean, I can tell you that after they heard this speech from George, within 15 minutes, everyone was in their rooms with their blankets pulled over their faces. And I mean, it was just really, really sad. There were a lot of people who were going to the clinic, a lot of people who were refusing to eat, a lot of people who were refusing to take their medication. There were concerns at the center that people might try to kill themselves. They had extra security there because they weren't sure what people were going to do, that people might kill themselves.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Then, six days later, as you've probably heard, a judge in Washington issued a restraining order blocking the Trump administration's travel ban. After that, the State Department issued instructions that all the refugees who were stopped now could come to the United States and they should rebook their flights to arrive here before February 17th. That applies to these Somali refugees, who, by the end of the week, had been sent back to the refugee camp but now will be returned to the transit center to fly to the United States very soon-- unless something changes.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Ahmed told Kevin that, just a few days before the executive order was signed, in the cultural orientation class to prepare them for what it's going to be like to live in America, the instructors described the country this way.

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: They said Americans, they don't discriminate people. They usually will come-- all the people, all the nations, they don't look that you came from Somalia, that you came from Kenya, from Syria, from Iran, from Russia, they don't look, from China, they don't look. All people are seen in America.

ep-609.speaker: kevin sieff
ep-609.utterance: And the orientation, that was like three days ago.

ep-609.speaker: ahmed
ep-609.utterance: Exactly.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Kevin asked him, how do you make sense of this executive order which does, in fact, single out people from just a few countries, including his. Ahmed said he didn't know how to make sense of it. He's just a student, he said. He's not a politician.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Act One, Basket of Deportables.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: So the same day as those Somalis were getting that news, here in the United States at airports around the country, there were protesters, hundreds of volunteer lawyers. A lot of that was on TV. Maybe you saw it. One of our producers, Zoe Chace, was at JFK Airport, terminal 4 on Saturday as customs agents stalled out, waiting for instructions from above. Around the country, there was confusion over who to let in and who to keep out. It seemed like they were erring on the side just holding everybody till they heard from Washington.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Zoe hung out with the lawyers for a while, like Becca Heller from the International Refugee Assistance Project. Her team had been at the airport since the night before, trying to get information from Customs and Border Protection, CBP.

ep-609.speaker: becca heller
ep-609.utterance: When we talked to CBP last night and asked who we could speak to, they told us to call the president.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Donald Trump.

ep-609.speaker: becca heller
ep-609.utterance: Yes. They specified that the president was Donald Trump in case we weren't aware of that. So a lot of our clients who were being held yesterday, Customs and Border Patrol just kept telling them, we're waiting for a call from DC to tell us what to do.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Really?

ep-609.speaker: becca heller
ep-609.utterance: And I don't know who was supposed to be on the other end of the phone. Is Mike Pence calling them up and telling them what to do? Nobody knows.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: All day the lawyers couldn't see their clients. Zoe and the other reporters couldn't see them or talk to them. They were hidden away somewhere back in the airport. And there's all this mystery about what was happening with these people who had arrived from the seven banned countries.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: In the days that followed, over the course of this week, Zoe tried to answer that question about what was going on back there.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: While Becca and I and the masses of other reporters and lawyers were stuck in the arrivals terminal outside the Dunkin' Donuts, here's what her client Haider was doing right at this moment. He was sitting quietly among dozens of people with no phone in a little room just a few minutes walk from where we were. He'd started off in another terminal, trying for hours to ask the customs officer, what's going on?

ep-609.speaker: haider
ep-609.utterance: What's the problem? Relax. Relax. Sit down. Relax.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: You know, my English isn't that great, so I would ask like, what's the problem? They'd be like, sit down. Relax.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: I reached Haider by phone a few days after the JFK episode. We spoke through an interpreter. He says when he got off the plane, he never even made it to customs. There were lots of people waiting around, which confused him. And a woman led him into a little room.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: They still had my passport, and so I was there like four hours just sitting and waiting.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Haider had been trying for three years to come to America. He fled Iraq a year and a half ago, found his way to Sweden. His wife had worked for an American contractor in Baghdad and their lives were threatened because of it. She and their son have been in Houston for those three years, trying to get him a visa. He got that visa to come to the United States on January 27, 2017. That was executive order day. His flight left Stockholm at 12:00 PM New York time on Friday. While he was in the air, the order went into effect. Haider didn't know that. He didn't know the order existed, that things have changed. His mind was racing.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: I'm telling them like, I can't go back to Iraq. I can't go back there, and I can go back to Stockholm because I gave up my right to be there once I came here. And I did everything, and it took three years. And my family's already living here. I have my wife and my son and my wife's family, and everybody's in Houston. And I did this, and it took me three years. Then you told me to come. I'm coming, and now you're telling me I can't come.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: He couldn't call his wife, Dunya, who was waiting in Houston, but she had a good idea why he might be late. She had Fox News on Friday afternoon.

ep-609.speaker: dunya
ep-609.utterance: I was at work, and I just put the headphones in my ear, and I was listening. And I just broke down when I heard the news. I just left. I couldn't stay in my place.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: You were crying.

ep-609.speaker: dunya
ep-609.utterance: Yeah. It was a really hard time for me.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: And what were you scared of?

ep-609.speaker: dunya
ep-609.utterance: I'm scared because if they let him go, all the three years is going to be returned again, you know?

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: You'll have to just do the whole three years over, the whole vetting process.

ep-609.speaker: dunya
ep-609.utterance: Yeah.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Back at the airport, Haider was stood up against a wall and searched. They put him in handcuffs. They took him to a car.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: Like, I don't know. Like, I can't-- I can't describe it. It was just-- you're just there. This is the first time in my life somebody has ever put handcuffs on me-- and without reason, too. The first time in my life.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: In the car was an Iranian and another Iraqi also in handcuffs. They drove to terminal 4, the terminal where the lawyers and I were. He got taken into another room. CBP took the handcuffs off and told them why they were there.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: One of the officers was telling us that this is what Trump said. If you're from this country, if you're from Iraq, and even if you have a visa and everything, you're still going to be sent back to your country. Then I was saying, I was in Sweden before this. I had a visa there and everything. You can't send me back to Iraq because the second I get set back there, I'm going to die.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: And what did they say to you when you said that?

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: He said, I can't do anything for you.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: I was just at that point that I just went and I sat. And I was just like, I don't know if we were all allowed a phone call or whatever, but once they kept telling you and telling you you're going to go back, I was almost defeated. So I was like, you have to let me call my wife and let her know what's happening because she doesn't know. So I have to let her know. And then they just gave me the phone to call.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Dunya, what happened in the phone call?

ep-609.speaker: dunya
ep-609.utterance: He called me at 1 o'clock. He said, they will send me back, so don't be sad. And he said, I can't go back to Sweden, so they will send me to Baghdad. And I couldn't talk. And my sister called Julie. She's my lawyer. And she said, just tell him, don't sign anything.

ep-609.speaker: julie
ep-609.utterance: Yes, I am here. We have a lot of people here waiting for him.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Julie, the lawyer in JFK, keeps getting calls from Dunya's sister over the next few hours. She keeps her earbuds permanently in her ears and periodically shouts things out, like I am at the airport ready to assist.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Any word on your client?

ep-609.speaker: julie
ep-609.utterance: Unfortunately no. Last I was told is we are waiting for the Secretary of State and Secretary of Homeland Security's signature.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: I don't think we have a Secretary of State.

ep-609.speaker: julie
ep-609.utterance: Tell me about it.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: The customs official comes out at one point into the crowd of lawyers. She says, come on back, but only two congressmen, Nadler of the 10th District of New York and Velazquez of the 7th, are allowed to follow her.

ep-609.speaker: julie
ep-609.utterance: It says "no lawyers." See if you can read what they're trying to get him to sign.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: Haider told me he stayed in that room at the terminal for another 10 hours. At some point, they brought him chicken and biscuits. One by one, he watched people leave. Haider was not interrogated, like was reported at other airports with other people who were held up. His wife waited, cried, texted the lawyers.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: We asked the White House to help us understand what was happening. We got no response. But I read The Washington Post. Here's what the administration told reporters on a conference call. The news media needs to calm down their, quote, "false, misleading, inaccurate, hyperventilating coverage" of the, quote, "fractional, marginal, minuscule percentage of international travelers who have simply been," as the reporter puts it, "set aside for further questioning for a couple hours on their way into the greatest country in the world." And OK, sure, a couple hours. Even 10 hours. Even 24 hours is not a big deal if you know what happens at the end-- that you get to come take refuge in America like you were promised. It is a big deal if you spend 10 hours worrying you're going to be flown off to a place where you're going to be killed, and your wife spends those hours thinking she'll never see you again.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: 6:30 PM, 22 hours later, Haider walks out into the arrivals area with everybody waiting. According to his lawyer Julie, five minutes after being told no, no, no, he cannot leave, apparently CBP suddenly changed its mind. They got a phone call and then they said, he can go. His lawyers think it's because they filed a habeas corpus suit, but really we don't know. We might never know. He came out with no documentation of what happened, which is extremely unusual.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: And so Haider is here in America with Dunya. The customs officials were nice about it when they let him go.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: Then after, they came to me and they said, OK, we finished everything. And you can go to Dunya now.

ep-609.speaker: interpreter
ep-609.utterance: I mean, to get out there and to see all of these people that stayed up this late, and they left their homes and their jobs and everything, and they're here for the sole purpose of standing with us. It's so beautiful.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: It's reported later that there was basically no prep on the government's part for how to deal with this. Apparently, this executive order was signed after very little consultation with Homeland Security or the State Department or the Department of Justice-- the guys in charge of this sort of thing.

ep-609.speaker: zoe chace
ep-609.utterance: As this week went on, the more that came out, the more confused it sounded. Like the green card holders. At first, it seemed like the green card holders were banned. Homeland Security, late Friday night, said, no, not green card holders. Then the White House overruled Homeland Security, like, green card holders, still out, basically. On Sunday, the White House said, OK, fine, Homeland Security, let's just do some extra screening of the green card holders. On Tuesday, the new Secretary of Homeland Security said the rollout went smoothly. On Thursday, the White House said, never mind. No additional screening for green card holders. Also this week, Congress requested an internal investigation into the Department of Homeland Security, into the way this policy got rolled out.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Zoe Chace. Haider's case, by the way-- a few hours after Haider's release was the case that led a New York judge to issue the first order halting deportations under the president's ban. Others obviously followed in the days after.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Act Two, Heavy Vetting.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: So the whole premise of the executive order is that we're going to stop all refugees and we're going to stop travelers from seven countries for a few months because we need to overhaul the way that we screen people before they come into the United States. Well, I talked to somebody who does that screening. He's on the staff of the United States Citizen and Immigration Services, USCIS. He's an interviewer. Flies to Africa and to the Mideast. He's interviewed Africans from all seven countries that we have temporarily banned. Sits with people for hours, drilling them on the details of their stories, looking for inconsistencies and lies. He asked that we not use his name or put his voice here on the radio, so I'm going to call him Bob. We have an actor, Scott Shepherd, saying what he said here on the air.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Bob said that when he and his colleagues heard about the executive order, the reaction was mostly shock and sadness. A few dozen of them went out for drinks together, and some people cried then.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Can I ask, did you cry?

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: On my own? Yes. In front of my friends? No.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: And so the news came down that this executive order came down, and so what happens to your work? What are you doing now?

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: When it came down, we basically came to a screeching halt. Most of us were getting on airplanes, and so we just literally had no work to do. So now we're all-- most likely, it looks like we're going to redeploy to the southern border, where we can do credible fear work. I'm not sure if you're--

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Do you mean you'll be doing with the border with Mexico, where you'll be doing credible fear work? That's people who want asylum and you have to interview them to figure out if they have a credible fear of getting killed?

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: Right, right.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Now, the whole premise for this executive order is that our ways of screening people to come into this country from these particular countries is not strong enough, and we're not doing a good enough job. And the president wants to put in something that he's calling extreme vetting. What do you think of that idea?

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: I find it personally offensive because it implies that those of us who vet refugees weren't doing extreme vetting before, that the work that I do as a refugee officer wasn't adequate to begin with. And I take the security of our country as my first priority. So I would never let someone in who I was suspicious of.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Bob and I talked for a while about the vetting procedures that are in place now. And they are considerable. People are fingerprinted. We take biometric data. In many countries, there are iris scans. Security checks are run by the FBI, the CIA, the Department of Defense, the National Security Agency, the National Counterterrorism Center, and sometimes others. They look at criminal databases and terrorism watch lists. They check family members' affiliations. They'll call contacts on people's smartphones. They have document verification labs. They compare the biometric information. And of course, they check people's social media accounts.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: The interviews Bob does are face to face. They take hours. A lawyer that I talked to who advocates for refugees seeking asylum, Laura Finkbeiner from the International Refugee Assistance Project, emphasized how these interviews are customized for each person.

ep-609.speaker: laura finkbeiner
ep-609.utterance: So they have a bunch of screening questions that they've particularly crafted, and they do this based on country. So they know if you're from a certain area at a certain time, there were certain groups active there. So they're checking to see-- they're asking you questions that are based specifically on your story, and they're making sure that what you're saying is credible, so it's consistent with what they know about the area at that given time.

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: And so we are looking for discrepancies in that information.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: I asked Bob about this.

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: Like, if those stories don't match, explain to me why not.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: And so basically, are you just running them through a million little details, trying to trip them up?

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: For the most part, yeah.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: And this has become an incredibly politicized question, but I hope you can answer it honestly. Are there times in your job where you feel like, oh, I really can't tell about this person and I wish I had more tools? I wish there was more I could do to figure this out better?

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: There are times that, because it's impossible to know about some people for whatever reason. But that's why we have a process. We're not letting people in that we have question marks about.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Oh. You're saying, if you can't figure it out, then they just don't get in.

ep-609.speaker: bob
ep-609.utterance: Right. Right.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: And all this brings us to something that is not just Bob's opinion. Many people believe that the current vetting system is effective. They'll tell you our current system's working. And as for the rare cases where somebody gets through, they'll say no system's perfect. No system can be perfect. We need studying learned from those cases.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: One of the people who said the system is effective to me most fiercely this week was Kirk Johnson. He's been on our program before. He worked for USAID in Iraq. And then when he came back to this country, he started the List Project to help interpreters and other Iraqis and Afghans who worked with the US overseas, whose lives were threatened because of it, move to this country. In that job, he's become very familiar with how hard it can be to get somebody into the US, even if they risk their lives helping American troops. He said it's tough.

ep-609.speaker: kirk johnson
ep-609.utterance: I'm really in this twilight zone because I'm seeing the President of the United States and his advisers try to draft policy to address a problem that doesn't exist.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: And what problem is that?

ep-609.speaker: kirk johnson
ep-609.utterance: Well, he campaigned by saying that we're not vetting these people. And the only way you can say that is if you don't know anything about how people are vetted. And you know, Trump's a busy guy. I don't expect him to sit down and learn the two-year vetting process in place by the US Refugee Admissions Program, but I sure as hell expect Steve Bannon or Steve Miller or any of the Steves who drafted this thing to just spend a few minutes and find out what is already in place. And I know for a fact that they did not go to the State Department's Refugee Processing people, the people that have been doing this for decades-- they never even got a basic briefing as to what currently exists.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: How do you know that they didn't consult with the State Department?

ep-609.speaker: kirk johnson
ep-609.utterance: I was on the phone with the State Department minutes before he signed it, asking whether or not these people that I was pushing were going to be able to board a plane that night.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: And this is in which office of the State Department?

ep-609.speaker: kirk johnson
ep-609.utterance: In the Population, Refugees, and Migration bureau.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: And that's who manages these programs to figure out who can come into the country?

ep-609.speaker: kirk johnson
ep-609.utterance: Right.

ep-609.speaker: ira glass
ep-609.utterance: Wait. And so you were on the phone with this person while the signing was happening?

ep-609.speaker: kirk johnson
ep-609.utterance: It was about three or four minutes beforehand, I reached out to this official at the State Department to say what's going to happen when she shows up to the airport, and he didn't know. And I said, how can you not know? Haven't they been coming and working this all out with you? And there was silence, and I pushed him. And he said, well, what do you want me to say? I'm sitting here refreshing the White House website just like you are.
